top_comment.text:
But how does the detritus get into the vitreous humour in the first place? 
And I see the sky sprites sometimes during orthostatic hypotension I think.﻿
top_comment.author: bobandquizo

comments.text:
The fetal eye has a channel to the lens which falls apart and as we age, 
the vitreous humor changes to produce floaters.  Red blood cells escape 
from the capillaries into the vitreous humor and swell up due to osmotic 
pressure and can link together. Except for parasites (very rare), nothing 
from outside gets into your eye.
comments.author: Michael Mauser

comments.text: They are debris from your development in the womb.
comments.author: William Wilson

comments.text: From normal aging I presume.  They said it could be old WBCs or proteins.
comments.author: MDkid1

comments.author: MarsTerraformer

comments.text: Yes.
comments.author: Michael Mauser

top_comment.text:
OK that explains 2 things. How about when you really focus on a wide solid 
colour, eg, a blue sky, and you start to see faint pulsating shadows? Kind 
of like geometric shape with transparent waves radiating from it.﻿
top_comment.author: Edward Bliss

comments.text:
What you might be seeing is the pulsating vascular tree entoptic 
phenomenon.  The suggested explanations for this phenomenon are that the 
arteries expand and contract with your pulse which moves the retina causing 
the sensation of light and changes the shape of the shadow making it 
visible.  I say a little more about this in my video "See inside your eye, 
Part 3: Using a moving light to see shadows of blood vessels on your retina"
comments.author: Michael Mauser

comments.text:
I've got the same thing. I have it anytime I look at the sky. I've 
explained it to my eye doctor and they didn't understand what I was seeing. 
I even drew her a picture of what I saw. I looked through these comments 
hoping I would see someone else with a similar problem. Sure wish I could 
do something about them because they are highly annoying at times.
comments.author: Edward Ratliff

comments.text:
+Jeff Tompas I really can't say much more than I already said without you 
answering my previous specific questions. Here are some more questions: Is 
the street light in focus? Do you see the same thing with each eye as you 
close them alternately?
comments.author: Michael Mauser

comments.text:
You know when it's foggy and you look at a street light and it had the glow 
globe around it? I see a circular pattern similar in shape as ( 
http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Earths_Magnetic_Field_Confusion.svg/2000px-Earths_Magnetic_Field_Confusion.svg.png 
) where the circle is the light and the dots move from one side inward and 
other outward (no circular motion as those arrows signify)
comments.author: Jeff “Zepplin76” Tompas

comments.text:
Can you describe that a little better?  Are there colors associated with 
this?  Do the dots move when you shift your eyes?  Are the dots numerous? 
 What size are the dots?  Etc.  The only thing that I can suggest right now 
is that it might be diffraction patterns.  These are common with point 
sources of light, and with lights which are not full spectrum, these 
patterns can be broken into different colors.  Floaters can cause these to 
seem to move when you shift your eyes.
comments.author: Michael Mauser

top_comment.text:
*Blue* *Field* *Entoptic* *Phenomenon* Is actually you seeing energy, this 
video is just a misinformative version of what you're really seeing, in 
favor of mainstream science. You don't have to agree with me, you don't 
have to believe a word I say.﻿
top_comment.author: Crows Descend

comments.text:
+van ivan To reiterate my earlier comment, 1) if you are not looking into a 
difuse light source with a blue light component, 2) if the movement is not 
in time with your pulse, 3) if the dots of light don't retrace their paths, 
and 4) if you can see it in the very center of your vision, what you are 
seeing in most likely NOT the blue field entoptic phenomenon.  It could be 
random noise (Prisoner's cinema) or any of a number of other things. 
 Please refer to the "Dig Deeper" section in TED-Ed for this video for more 
information.
comments.author: Michael Mauser

comments.text:
Sounds to me like mass hypnosis. Either they were altogether coming into or 
out of one (or even more than one). So what they saw either existed and was 
hidden before or didn't exist and was finally resolved in their minds as 
just a hallucination being projected from the past or a distance.
The question you seem to want to know is how they were all able to see 
those same things that had previously not been seen (or noticed) well I 
don't know for sure but to give my best explanation I'd compare it to the 
fine tuning on an old tv. Like focusing a lens you can see finer details 
more clearly or by unfocusing it you blur the details. And if an expert 
narration directed their attention to those details it didn't make them 
come into existence. It just calmed their minds enough so that they could 
see them. Or aggravated their minds enough so that they couldn't see them 
anymore, just like what psychiatric drugs or sports pep talks do so people 
can cope without feeling obliged to respond to so much that they would 
notice and feel bombarded with otherwise.
comments.author: Ananta Sesa das

comments.text:

but to my understanding this happened to people exposed to 
radiation,prolonged

This is only one part of energy a man sees in certain state of conscious 
other parts include persons and trees auras,grey or white smoke appearing 
and objects disappearing
comments.author: van ivan

comments.text:
From research done after my comment I encountered a phrase "prisoner's 
cinema". Look it up on wikipedia.
There is also a twilight zone episode called "where is everyone?" where the 
hallucination gets more extensive.
So you see karma can be intense. It's like a 5th dimension to our world. 
Something can look identical but have a vastly different psychological 
effect due to timing, sequence, arrangement, etc. from something else. That 
is how I attribute the "cinema" as originating. And people's "bubble boy" 
shortage of immunity comes from being so coddled with sterile presentations 
after so many censors to water down to a boring PC general standard.

Something vaguely related to that sterile topic is how pop musicians use 
autotune. Where are the innocent mistakes and natural human voice flutters?!

comments.author: van ivan

Yes it's energy, "light ray" energy. Coming through better where the red

comments.author: Ananta Sesa das

comments.text:
To distinguish between what you call energy and the blue field phenomenon 
try this.  With the blue field you see it only when your are looking at a 
bright field of white or blue light, you dont see it in the center of your 
vision because there are no capillaries on your retina there, and the 
moving dots follow the same paths over and over and increase in speed with 
your heart rate.  If these things are not true, you are seeing something 
else.  It could be random noise, or it could be due to other radiation.

top_comment.author: Francesca Crema

comments.text:

comments.author: Francesca Crema

comments.text:
Probably.  A point light source close to the eye will cast shadows on your 
retina of things on your cornea, in your lens, and within your eye, so you 
can see the tear film on your eye, cataracts in your lens, and all the 
floaters in your eye.  The droplets on the googles act as convex lenses 
making a small virtual image of the overhead lights close to your eye - 
essentially a point light source.  For more information see my video "See 
inside your eye, Part 1: Using a point light source to see floaters and 
cataracts" for more information.
comments.author: Michael Mauser

top_comment.text:
wait wait wait wait! you mean to tell me that a single red blood cell is 
big enough to cast a shadow? that goes for "clumps of protein" too? Last 
time i checked, proteins are smaller than DNA strands, yet i can SEE them?! 
Whoa!! What resolution is the human eye then?﻿
top_comment.author: Daniel Muriungi

comments.text:
Actually she's trying to explain that all these small things are clump of 
larger proteins and clump of cells not one cell or one protein
comments.author: shrishti tyagi

comments.text:
Actually, the red cells swell up due to osmotic pressure and what you see 
are the diffraction rings on the retina.  Clump enough protein together 
(cook an egg) and you can see it.  Actually, "clumps of protein" was 
intentially pretty vague, it got me out of going into detail on what it is 
exactly.  See the "Dig Deeper" section for more information.
comments.author: Michael Mauser

top_comment.text:
Sometimes, against a uniform, bright background such as a clear sky or a 
blank computer screen, you might see things floating across your field of 
vision. What are these moving objects, and how are you seeing them? Michael 
Mauser explains the visual phenomenon that is floaters.﻿

This is an excellent video. Really great explanation, and as someone who 
experiences floaters often and has asked optometrists about them, I can say 
this video has actually helped me understand them better. I have a question 
though: can anything be done medically to decrease the amount and frequency 
of them? I have always had floaters, but I experience them more often now 
than I did as a teenager, I'm concerned that by the time I'm 30 they'll be 
an every day occurrence, and possibly become intrusive to my vision by my 
40's and 50's.

falls alseep and then wakes up and you experience pins and needles, except

you don't get the pins and needles feeling, but you see it manifest itself 
in the form of what the video said. That could be totally wrong since it's

top_comment.text:
Michael, I have always enjoyed your videos, as the shed light on problems 
that most eye doctors don't even seem to know. I've had floaters like this, 
as well as Blue Field Entoptic Phenomenon for around 5 years now. It is 
constant. Can you shed any light on these symptoms being caused by anxiety? 
After seeing so many doctors over the years, my RX has basically been 
"overexciteability" or "hypersenitivity". Since I have accepted this fact 
for over a year now, my outlook on these symptoms have improved, as well as 
my fear of these frightening symptoms...

However, these problems still do persist, and I feel I will never enjoy a 
walk outside like I did for 27 years of my life before all these strange 
things started happening to my vision. Any insight would be greatly 
appreciated. Thanks!﻿
top_comment.author: Aaron Walker

comments.text:
+Michael Mauser
The autism reference makes me think of the difference between pixelated 
images and smooth forms. There are no perfectly smooth physical forms. They 
exist in our minds as a concept and that principle is what we need to use 
to filter out sensory inputs like the grid of a screen's pixels or our 
retina's resolution limit with veins and imperfection to see only macro or 
micro but not both simultaneously or the molecular crystalline structure 
seen in microscopes.
comments.author: Ananta Sesa das

comments.text:
I'm not a physician and since my focus is on things that are "normal", I 
don't really know a lot about problems people have.  About all I can say is 
that we do learn to ignore a great deal (background noise, smells, etc.) 
and at times we can become acutely aware of them, such as our heartbeat, 
when we are anxious.  I have read some books by Temple Grandin.  She 
describes her ordeals with autism; it seems to me that autistic people have 
a harder time ignoring sensory inputs, but she developed ways to deal with 
this.  Also, I have heard some good things about "mindfulness" techniques 
(see http://palousemindfulness.com/) with regard to dealing with long term 
stress.
comments.author: Michael Mauser

top_comment.text:

really tight I could see some orange/green/red sparkles. I wonder what kind 
of phenomenon is that...﻿
top_comment.author: chronousnemesis

comments.text:
The retina in the backs of your eyes is also pressure sensitive in addition 
to detecting light. You can also experience this if you close your eyes, 
look as far to your left as you can, then gently move your finger around on 
the far right corner of your right eye (towards your ear). A dot will 
appear towards your nose that moves as you move your finger, except the 
movement is mirrored.

eclipse appearance when putting pressure on your eyes and usually appear 
bluish white and circular whereas longer pressure can cut off the blood 
supply creating pressure that matches what's going on in your capillaries 
and you see fuzzy tingling images. Other time seeing something Brite stains 
your retina temporarily as your adjusting to a darker envoronment.

captions.text:
Have you ever noticed something swimming 
in your field of vision?

It may look like a tiny worm
or a transparent blob,

and whenever you try to get a closer look,
it disappears,

only to reappear 
as soon as you shift your glance.
But don't go rinsing out your eyes!

What you are seeing is a common phenomenon
known as a floater.

The scientific name for these objects
is Muscae volitantes,
Latin for "flying flies,"

and true to their name, 
they can be somewhat annoying.

But they're not actually bugs 
or any kind of external objects at all.
Rather, they exist inside your eyeball.

Floaters may seem to be alive,
since they move and change shape,
but they are not alive.

Floaters are tiny objects 
that cast shadows on the retina,

the light-sensitive tissue 
at the back of your eye.
They might be bits of tissue,
red blood cells,
or clumps of protein.

And because they're suspended
within the vitreous humor,

the gel-like liquid 
that fills the inside of your eye,

floaters drift along with
your eye movements,

and seem to bounce a little 
when your eye stops.

Floaters may be only 
barely distinguishable most of the time.

They become more visible 
the closer they are to the retina,

just as holding your hand 
closer to a table with an overhead light

will result in a more 
sharply defined shadow.
And floaters are particularly noticeable

when you are looking 
at a uniform bright surface,
like a blank computer screen,
snow,
or a clear sky,

where the consistency of the background 
makes them easier to distinguish.

The brighter the light is,
the more your pupil contracts.

This has an effect similar 
to replacing a large diffuse light fixture
with a single overhead light bulb,

which also makes
the shadow appear clearer.

There is another visual phenomenon
that looks similar to floaters
but is in fact unrelated.

If you've seen tiny dots of light
darting about
when looking at a bright blue sky,

you've experienced what is known as
the blue field entoptic phenomenon.

In some ways, 
this is the opposite of seeing floaters.
Here, you are not seeing shadows

but little moving windows 
letting light through to your retina.

The windows are actually caused 
by white blood cells

moving through the capillaries 
along your retina's surface.

These leukocytes can be so large
that they nearly fill a capillary

causing a plasma space 
to open up in front of them.
Because the space in the white blood cells
are both more transparent to blue light

than the red blood cells 
normally present in capillaries,

we see a moving dot of light 
wherever this happens,

following the paths of your capillaries
and moving in time with your pulse.
Under ideal viewing conditions,

you might even see what looks
like a dark tail following the dot.

This is the red blood cells 
that have bunched up behind the leukocyte.

Some science museums have an exhibit
which consists of a screen of blue light,

allowing you to see these blue sky sprites
much more clearly than you normally would.

While everybody's eyes experience 
these sort of effects,
the number and type vary greatly.
In the case of floaters,

they often go unnoticed
as our brain learns to ignore them.
However, abnormally numerous

or large floaters 
that interfere with vision

may be sign of a more serious condition,
requiring immediate medical treatment.

But the majority of the time 
entoptic phenomena,
such as floaters and blue sky sprites,

are just a gentle reminder 
that what we think we see

depends just as much 
on our biology and minds
as it does on the external world.

title: What are those floaty things in your eye? - Michael Mauser
